page.title: 05FARMING:THE FARMER'S YEAR
page.content: A farmer's day varies according to the season. In early spring fences have to be made stock-proof, fertilizer is sown on the grass and the fields ploughed, prepared and tilled with spring corn. Winter corn is sown sim- ilarly in autumn. When the corn is a few inches high in late spring it is sprayed to prevent weeds from growing. Late spring sheep are docked before shearing in early summer. During summer, there are silage, hay and corn harvests, and dipping of sheep (also in autumn). Late summer weeds are cut in grass fields. In autumn potatoes, sugar beet and other root crops are harvested. Hedges are cut. Winter brings the lambing season, the making of hedges, and the continual tending to livestock housed until signs of spring. Mrs June Butt (Farmer's wife)
